Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http.client

Class HTTPClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.Connector
      • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.Client
        • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http.client.HTTPClient
  • public class HTTPClient
extends Client
    HTTP client implementation that creates and manages HTTP connections.

    This class extends Client to provide HTTP-specific client functionality for connecting to HTTP servers, creating connections, and making HTTP requests.

    An HTTPClient represents a connection (or pool of connections) to a single server. It provides factory methods for creating requests, manages connection state, and supports both HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 protocols.

    Simple Usage

    For most use cases, simply create the client and make requests. The connection is established automatically when the first request is made: 

    
 HTTPClient client = new HTTPClient("api.example.com", 443);
 client.setSecure(true);

 client.get("/users").send(new DefaultHTTPResponseHandler() {
     public void ok(HTTPResponse response) {
         System.out.println("Success: " + response.getStatus());
     }
     public void responseBodyContent(ByteBuffer data) {
         // Process response body
     }
     public void close() {
         client.close();
     }
     public void failed(Exception ex) {
         // Connection or request error
         ex.printStackTrace();
     }
 });

    With Connection Events

    If you need to receive connection lifecycle events (e.g., to log TLS negotiation or handle disconnects), use #connect(HTTPClientHandler): 

    
 HTTPClient client = new HTTPClient("api.example.com", 443);
 client.setSecure(true);
 client.connect(new HTTPClientHandler() {
     public void onConnected(ConnectionInfo info) {
         client.get("/users").send(responseHandler);
     }
     public void onTLSStarted(TLSInfo info) {
         System.out.println("TLS: " + info.getProtocol());
     }
     public void onError(Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
     public void onDisconnected() { }
 });

    Server Integration (with SelectorLoop affinity)

    
 // Use the same SelectorLoop as your server connection for efficiency
 HTTPClient client = new HTTPClient(connection.getSelectorLoop(), "api.example.com", 443);
 client.setSecure(true);
 client.get("/data").send(handler);

    POST with Request Body

    
 HTTPRequest request = client.post("/api/users");
 request.header("Content-Type", "application/json");
 request.startRequestBody(handler);
 request.requestBodyContent(ByteBuffer.wrap(jsonBytes));
 request.endRequestBody();

    HTTP/2 Concurrent Requests

    When connected via HTTP/2, multiple requests can be in flight simultaneously: 

    
 // Check if multiplexing is supported
 if (client.getVersion() != null &amp;&amp; client.getVersion().supportsMultiplexing()) {
     // Fire off multiple requests concurrently
     for (String path : paths) {
         client.get(path).send(handler);
     }
 }

    Authentication

    
 client.credentials("admin", "secret");
 client.get("/protected/resource").send(handler);
 // If server returns 401, client automatically retries with auth
    Author:
    Chris Burdess
    See Also:
    HTTPClientHandler, HTTPRequest, HTTPResponseHandler

    • Constructor Detail

      • HTTPClient

        public HTTPClient​(java.lang.String host,
                  int port)
           throws java.net.UnknownHostException
        Creates an HTTP client that will connect to the specified host and port.

        The Gumdrop infrastructure is managed automatically - it starts when Client.connect(T) is called and stops when all connections close.

        Parameters:
        host - the HTTP server host as a String
        port - the HTTP server port number (typically 80 or 443)
        Throws:
        java.net.UnknownHostException - if the host cannot be resolved

      • HTTPClient

        public HTTPClient​(SelectorLoop selectorLoop,
                  java.lang.String host,
                  int port)
           throws java.net.UnknownHostException
        Creates an HTTP client that will connect to the specified host and port, using the provided SelectorLoop for I/O.

        Use this constructor for server integration where you want the client to share a SelectorLoop with server connections for efficiency.

        Parameters:
        selectorLoop - the SelectorLoop for connection I/O
        host - the HTTP server host as a String
        port - the HTTP server port number (typically 80 or 443)
        Throws:
        java.net.UnknownHostException - if the host cannot be resolved

      • request

        public HTTPRequest request​(java.lang.String method,
                           java.lang.String path)
        Creates a request with a custom HTTP method.

        Use this for non-standard methods or methods not covered by the convenience methods (e.g., "PROPFIND" for WebDAV).

        Parameters:
        method - the HTTP method
        path - the request path
        Returns:
        a new request
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if not connected

      • credentials

        public void credentials​(java.lang.String username,
                        java.lang.String password)
        Sets credentials for HTTP authentication.

        When credentials are configured, the client handles authentication challenges (401/407 responses) automatically:

        1. If the server responds with 401, the client examines the WWW-Authenticate header
        2. The client computes the appropriate authorization (Basic or Digest)
        3. The request is automatically retried with the authorization header
        4. The handler only receives the final response (success or failure)

        Example: 

        
 client.credentials("admin", "secret");
 client.get("/protected/resource").send(handler);
 // If server returns 401, client automatically retries with auth
        Parameters:
        username - the username
        password - the password

      • clearCredentials

        public void clearCredentials()
        Clears any configured credentials.

        After calling this method, authentication challenges will not be handled automatically.

      • isOpen

        public boolean isOpen()
        Returns true if the client is connected and can accept new requests.

        Returns false if not connected, after the client is closed, after receiving a GOAWAY frame (HTTP/2), or after a fatal connection error.

        Returns:
        true if the client is open and connected

      • getVersion

        public HTTPVersion getVersion()
        Returns the negotiated HTTP version, or null if not yet connected.

        For TLS connections, the version is determined by ALPN negotiation during the TLS handshake. For plaintext connections, it depends on HTTP/2 upgrade negotiation or the server's response.

        Use this to check if multiplexing is available: 

        
 if (client.getVersion() != null && client.getVersion().supportsMultiplexing()) {
     // Safe to make concurrent requests
 }
        Returns:
        the HTTP version, or null if not yet known

      • getActiveConnection

        public HTTPClientConnection getActiveConnection()
        Returns the current connection, or null if not connected.

        This method provides access to the underlying connection for advanced usage. Most applications should use the request factory methods directly on this client instead.

        Returns:
        the current connection, or null

      • setH2Enabled

        public void setH2Enabled​(boolean enabled)
        Enables or disables HTTP/2 via ALPN for TLS connections.

        When enabled (the default), TLS connections will offer "h2" in ALPN negotiation, allowing the server to select HTTP/2 if it supports it.

        Disable this if you specifically need to use HTTP/1.1 over TLS, for example to test HTTP/1.1 behaviour or connect to servers with HTTP/2 issues.

        Parameters:
        enabled - true to offer HTTP/2 in ALPN negotiation

      • isH2Enabled

        public boolean isH2Enabled()
        Returns whether HTTP/2 via ALPN is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if HTTP/2 via ALPN is enabled

      • setH2cUpgradeEnabled

        public void setH2cUpgradeEnabled​(boolean enabled)
        Enables or disables h2c (HTTP/2 over cleartext) upgrade attempts.

        When enabled (the default), plaintext HTTP connections will attempt to upgrade to HTTP/2 using the h2c upgrade mechanism. Most servers don't support this, but attempting it is harmless.

        Disable this if you specifically need to test or use HTTP/1.1 only.

        Parameters:
        enabled - true to attempt h2c upgrade on plaintext connections

      • isH2cUpgradeEnabled

        public boolean isH2cUpgradeEnabled()
        Returns whether h2c upgrade is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if h2c upgrade is enabled

      • setH2WithPriorKnowledge

        public void setH2WithPriorKnowledge​(boolean enabled)
        Enables or disables HTTP/2 with prior knowledge.

        When enabled on a plaintext (non-TLS) connection, the client will immediately send the HTTP/2 connection preface (PRI * HTTP/2.0...) without first attempting an h2c upgrade handshake.

        This should only be enabled when you know the server supports HTTP/2, as the connection will fail if the server doesn't understand HTTP/2.

        This setting is mutually exclusive with h2c upgrade - if prior knowledge is enabled, h2c upgrade is bypassed.

        Parameters:
        enabled - true to use HTTP/2 with prior knowledge on plaintext connections

      • isH2WithPriorKnowledge

        public boolean isH2WithPriorKnowledge()
        Returns whether HTTP/2 with prior knowledge is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if HTTP/2 with prior knowledge is enabled

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the client gracefully.

        For HTTP/2, this sends a GOAWAY frame allowing outstanding requests to complete. For HTTP/1.x, this closes the connection after any in-progress request completes.

        Any requests that have not yet received a response will have their handler's HTTPResponseHandler.failed(Exception) method called.

      • getDescription

        public java.lang.String getDescription()
        Description copied from class: Connector
        Returns a short (one word) description of this connector.
        Overrides:
        getDescription in class Client
